benchmark_details.name: HaluEval 2.0
benchmark_details.overview: A benchmark designed for evaluating the factuality hallucination in large language models, consisting of 8,770 questions across multiple domains.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To systematically study hallucinations in LLMs focusing on detection, source, and mitigation.

data.source: Multiple domain datasets including BioASQ, NFCorpus, FiQA-2018, SciFact, LearningQ, and HotpotQA.
data.annotation: Questions selected based on difficulty and likelihood of hallucination.

methodology.calculation: MiHR and MaHR are calculated based on the number of hallucinatory statements in responses.
methodology.interpretation: Lower values indicate better performance in hallucination mitigation.
methodology.validation: Validated via comparison with human labeling for reliability.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: No personal data was used in the construction of the dataset.
